text:
Hi all. I'm sure this is possible, I'm just not familiar enough with DataFrames.jl to know which function to use in this case. My data looks like this:
```22×3 DataFrame
 Row │ step   nutrients  replicate 
     │ Int64  Float64    Int64     
─────┼─────────────────────────────
   1 │     0    1.00504          1
   2 │     1    1.03524          1
   3 │     2    1.07272          1
   4 │     3    1.07911          1
   5 │     4    1.10866          1
   6 │     5    1.04709          1
   7 │     6    1.01967          1
   8 │     7    1.0493           1
   9 │     8    1.09155          1
  10 │     9    1.08902          1
  11 │    10    1.20758          1
  12 │     0    1.00504          2
  13 │     1    1.03524          2
  14 │     2    1.07272          2
  15 │     3    1.07911          2
  16 │     4    1.10866          2
  17 │     5    1.04709          2
  18 │     6    1.01967          2
  19 │     7    1.0493           2
  20 │     8    1.09155          2
  21 │     9    1.08902          2
  22 │    10    1.20758          2```
I'd like to reshape it so that I have `step`, `nutrients_1`, `nutrients_2` . So basically a 10x3 dataframe as the output.

text: the naming of the columns won't be what you want, though

elements.text: the naming of the columns won't be what you want, though

text: ah, you can fix the naming by using `unstack(df, :step, :replicate, :nutrients, renamecols = x -> Symbol(:nutrients_, x))`
